title: 155. Helping People Die | People I (Mostly) Admire

rawLines.text: [Music]
Most doctors focus on prolonging human
life, but not today's guest. Ellen Weave
is a physician who spends her days
ending lives. I have had these wonderful
conversations with so many people where
I say now that you have the approval to
go ahead, when would you like to die?
Where would you like to die? Who do you
want to invite to your death? Anything
special you want at the day?
Welcome to People I Mostly Admire with
Steve Levit. Ellen Weeb lives and works
in Canada where medical assistance and
dying or maid mid as it's abbreviated is
not only legal, it's widely practiced.
Almost 5% of all Canadian deaths are the
result of physician assistance. I began
our conversation by asking Helen to
explain the history of Canada's law
enabling medical assistance in
[Music]
dying. It was 2015 that Canadians were
given this right. There was a court
case. It was based on a K. Carter, who
had gone to Switzerland in order to get
an assisted death, and her family
brought the case to say that she
shouldn't have had to go to Switzerland,
that she had the right to control her
own death and should have been able to
have it in her own country. And then we
got our law in 2016 in June. and they
added a whole lot of safeguards, rules,
regulations that we all had to follow.
Over the years, there have been one
court challenge after another. So what
we have now is that people are allowed
to request an assisted death if they
have a grievous and irrediable medical
condition, are suffering
unbearably, and are in an advanced state
of decline of
capability, and they must have the
ability to consent.
Of course, Canada isn't the only place
that has assisted dying. As you said,
Switzerland, I think it's been legal
since 1942 or something like that. The
Netherlands, it's been legal there and
in Belgium since the early 2000s. And
there are a handful of other countries
where it's allowed. I was surprised
myself to discover that it's legal in 10
US states. I was aware of Oregon and
Washington that really got a lot of
media coverage when it was approved
there. But even in the states in the US
where it's legal, it's not used that
much. So per capita the rate in Oregon
is about maybe 1/4 or 1/5if of the rate
in Canada even though it's legalized
almost 20 years earlier in Oregon and
the rate in Oregon is higher than the
rest of the other US states. Do you
understand why there's so much more in
Canada? Is the process simpler? Is the
set of allowable conditions broader? I
thought about this one a lot. We think
of California because their law came in
at the same year ours did and their
population is similar to Canada's. It
looks like about 85% of the people who
access assisted dying in Canada would
have be eligible in California where
it's required that you're within 6
months of a natural death. And yet we
have so much more. Why is that? Well,
there's a number of reasons. One is that
there was immediately a group, including
me, who believed that this was a right
that people should have access to. And
we formed an organization called the
Canadian Association of Made Assessors
and Providers. We trained other doctors
and we supported them and we set
standards that were beyond what the
government set in terms of really good
care. You have to have somebody to do it
and then we got government buyin in most
places. So it's different across the
country. Health is provided locally in
provinces and in health authorities. And
my health authority has a maid
coordinating office where patients can
call, get all the information they need,
get connected to assessors and providers
so that they can access. So access is a
big issue. Also media people have to
know about their choices. In the first
years, we had great media coverage with
wonderful people who gave their own
stories of how they came to decide that
they would want an assisted death at the
end. All of those things, the fact that
our law does not require a terminal
illness, the fact that we have a strong
group of providers and we have a
government that I shouldn't say
government, we have governments,
provincial health authority,
jurisdictions that believe people should
have support through the end of life.
Could you describe the steps involved in
medically assisted dying in Canada? So,
let's say I have terminal cancer. I'm in
intense pain. What do I need to do to
get approval for an assisted death? So,
you would ask your doctor if you're in
the hospital, your nurse, or you'd call
the coordinating center. They would
bring a written request form that must
be witnessed by an independent witness.
So, that means somebody who doesn't
benefit from your death. And then get
two assessors. These are doctors or
nurse practitioners who would do an
assessment to make sure you fit all of
the criteria to have a legal assisted
death and then it would get organized.
Unlike most of the states that have
assisted dying, we have the ability to
do things quite quickly. Somebody's in
crisis in the hospital, they probably
just need really good paliotative care.
But sometimes they say, "No, what I want
is to leave and we can, you know, pull
it together quickly in an urgent case
like that." And I've had the wonderful
experiences of families coming together
to give their loved one, you know, the
best possible send off. Yeah. Yeah,
because we'll probably describe it and
talk about it as a medical procedure as
we talk about it today. But really,
first and foremost, it's a right of
passage, right? It's not that different
from birth or graduation or a wedding.
To me, one of the beauties of it is that
you have the opportunity to put the kind
of thought into that right of passage,
which is absent in the typical death
because it's uncertain and everyone's on
call. No one really knows when it'll
happen. But more than that, you know,
the person who is dying is there. I've
been a doctor for almost 50 years and I
have been around lots of other deaths.
And in those cases, the person leaves
sooner than them when they die. They
almost always go into a coma before and
even before that they are so sick, so
weak, they no longer
converse. This is different. people
actually plan their last words. Mhm.
Yeah. Yeah. It's interesting to think
about because in most medical
situations, a lot of the treatment is
doctor initiated, right? The doctor
says, "Here's the situation and I would

an acceptable thing for you as a doctor
to say, "Hey, you're really sick. Is

We are allowed. There are jurisdictions

life, they need to give them options in

So when you give someone the option of

thing to do because
people should have all their choices put

in oncology they hate telling the

are dying and they're going to die soon.
So they they keep on treating them
because it's easier for the doctor. I
imagine that is even worse with this
idea of assisted suicide. You're at home
with it. You do it. But for the
90 plus% of doctors who are out there

if they just avoid that conversation
because it's unpleasant. Exactly. What
you're saying is it's the entire
conversation. the
conversation. When somebody has a

What's available for comfort care at

Just like the Netherlands, they're

And then when everybody's ready, I give

general anesthetic is propol and we use

about 5 minutes. Well, really fast.
Yeah. It's interesting. Really fast.
Yeah. I delivered over a thousand babies

room at that
time. It sounds medically really pretty

Roughly how often would you say there's
an important complication? Oh, less than

IV goes interstitial, meaning that it's

have been a few
occasions, once for me, once for another

to get the IV. And with the oral, there

the family has said their final goodbyes
and we just take care of it. In the US,

the activists claim that they botch it

how they've failed and had to restart it

doctors. The prison officials who were
trying to do it. Yeah. In our case, it
was doctors. It was medically organized
and it doesn't fail. I mean, we get
access and we give enough medication and
it always works. I don't even think
they're using the same drugs in the US.
I know there's been a big controversy.
The drug suppliers, I think it's
bentoarbital or something like that. the

having heard you describe it, it's an
even bigger puzzle to me than it's

ineffective at doing this. Yeah. Nobody
wants to help them execute people. I
think
we'll be right back with more of my
conversation with physician Ellen Weeb

You spent most of your career as a

deliveries as you described before.
Extending your practice to assisted

So in 2015 when we knew that the law was

I only know one paliotative care doctor.
It's a guy named BJ Miller who I've had

assisted death. And it's because of the

patients. And when their patients would

that people are offered the full range

I said to one of my abortion providing

and I went to the Netherlands and got

So that's where I went to find out more.
Assisted dying is one of those topics

thinks about it, it's really hard for me
to come up with any really good
counterarguments for assisted dying, but
we haven't really made the full case for
it. Could I give you the chance to just
explain what your case is for assisted
dying? It's human right. That is my
basis. We have the right to control our

what they do with accidental
pregnancies. And that just translates

way. And it's so different from suicide.
In suicide, you have to be alone because

patients, I asked him how he saw this

Now when that part is over, instead of

there's the commandments, thou shalt not

and since I've been disabled and using a

you're not in their body. They are.
There's no question that disabled people

about me as if I'm not there. really
because I'm the one in the wheelchair.
Other people get a whole lot more of
that if a disabled person says they want

"Wow, they're so disabled. Why would
they want to go through cancer
treatments? They should just die." Well,
the point is that person has the right

horrible shelter with caregivers whom he

wait.
you've totally made the case for this

and I have to look for that. That's part

much
worse." And so they are now no longer
